64795F8280F540DEBC13BF65E0B15F3E.description: Propose ideas for new products that would help humans address various types of weather conditions.

8C83ADC357B841E592F2616999979D52.description: Explain why forecasting, measuring, and understanding weather is important for humans.

DE671959195D43C78E081B6A49178D6C.description: Research traditional and contemporary technological innovations and products related to clothing, shelter, agriculture, and transportation that various cultures have developed to address various types of weather conditions.

29ECA5CF82F54D82BB2B5227B31039C4.description: Examine how scientists and traditional knowledge keepers can collaborate to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the effects of weather on people and the environment.

2F46F47623DE470989D5CE05A25D01AE.description: Explain the effects of different types of severe weather on people, communities, and the environment, including personal safety preparations for various severe weather events.

9C92854A0E0F4CF6ADAECAA50283C5C9.description: Relate weather conditions, and changing weather conditions, to the activities and behaviours of animals.

951EA6DFF8704475B11E1E24452F130D.description: Research effects of short- and long-term changes in weather on the lives and livelihoods of people locally, nationally, and globally.

8F29C68E237C4290B4EAAE511C90A121.description: Analyze the impact of weather conditions for a particular region on the lives and livelihoods of people in that region, including choices of food, shelter, clothing, transportation, and employment.

2F63071CF1D64DB8891A1F6F9F790B92.description: Research how and why people in their communities use short- and long-term weather forecasts in their daily lives

0FA60DF5758C4A1BABE835708F173315.description: Explain the purpose of different types of information (e.g., satellite and radar maps, weather watches and warnings, summary statistics, travel advisories, and air quality reports) that weather forecasters provide.

05DD1DD06D2C4C9D848F9B5BE096D433.description: Analyze the impact of weather on society and the environment, including technologies that help humans adddress weather conditions.

147C9BED66734997855F4EDB29541B47.description: Identify examples of local, national, and global weather phenomena that Canadian scientists are currently studying (e.g., UV protection, wind chill, ozone layer, seasonal snow cover, and temperature trends).

378B94A97AE648FFB781A8D515116D14.description: Suggest explanations for patterns or discrepancies between predictions of weather patterns and actual data for a given location during a given time interval.

5BC0DC08EAD548C088A7F44CEDAC874B.description: Predict patterns in local, regional, and global weather over a given time frame (e.g., a day, a week, a month, and a year).

D38136A7A3A74C8EAF23614D25170D26.description: Examine weather lore and animal behaviours in traditional and contemporary cultures as tools to predict weather conditions.

72F8D9084E444C0B984B3DC938F457DF.description: Compare weather conditions locally, regionally, and across Canada at various times throughout the year.

90AEFDCFA4A042A98ACABCB142E33F4B.description: Relate weather extremes (e.g., hottest air temperature, lowest air temperature, greatest rainfall, highest wind speed, and heaviest hailstone) to specific locations in Canada and on Earth.

90D35FC2A2114ACEB59ABC9179C4A558.description: Describe the characteristics of severe weather events, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, blizzards, hailstorms, droughts, and tropical cyclones, including the role of air movement and solar energy transfer in those events.

6BFB2B65C4B64976AC5E8C29275DFEB5.description: Relate the transfer of energy from the sun to the heating of Earth’s surface by providing examples of surfaces that heat at different rates and locations (e.g., desert, forest, island, and summerfallow field) that have different temperatures.

8EA343F9FED04347835945C2DB165623.description: Develop simple conclusions about the relationship between the amount of energy absorbed by a material and the nature of the material.

F1A0E678117C47628AFC911C90CCEBC9.description: Record and share, using tables, charts, diagrams, and graphs, the results of experimentation into the effects of solar energy on different surfaces.

2DFC1502EB0447049095E85BA330C26B.description: Design and safely carry out an experiment to determine the effects of solar energy on different surfaces (e.g., water, soil, sand, asphalt, concrete, grass, and wood).

2949D5712DC64C65BE8DF0D187355E05.description: Measure, describe, and represent patterns in indoor and local outdoor air movement.

7E1304615B174951B2437C2253A94421.description: Demonstrate properties of air, in that air takes up space, has weight, expands and rises when heated, exerts pressure, and moves from areas of high pressure to areas of low pressure.

6E3050871F25459688B4488E142EB903.description: Pose questions about the characteristics of local, national, and global weather conditions.

47E8341B9A184133874BB3806E4D40ED.description: Investigate local, national, and global weather conditions, including the role of air movement and solar energy transfer.

170F92846A5745C58C74802656AA73AB.description: Pose new questions about local weather conditions based on what was learned.

5C9652A242DF4241A4F05617ED9BB0D9.description: Generate simple conclusions about the prevailing local weather conditions.

7EEF7E933F4843F4A32F37DCAD93C7A1.description: Analyze patterns and discrepancies in weather data for a given location over a specified time interval.

9ABFDEB263C845D59303FDF3A53FFCBC.description: Construct a sample weather map for their region, indicating the temperature, wind speed and direction, precipitation, and cloud cover at a given time.

5364A927203F46D5915FB6C2CCDB884B.description: Evaluate, using student-developed criteria, the effectiveness of a personally-constructed weather instrument.

B8C13D374F1B4746B1AE1CE7EEC4203B.description: Construct a wind rose to determine the predominant wind direction in a region over a given time period.

D9D739C3E5E24DD8852F91137051715C.description: Compile and display local weather data (e.g., temperature, wind speed and direction, amount of sunlight, precipitation, relative humidity, and cloud cover) for a given time interval (e.g., hourly throughout the day, daily for one week, and weekly for one month) using a weather journal, tables, charts, diagrams, and graphs.

946ACBDD5B554D9B8541B358E1718EE0.description: Explain the function and purpose of simple weather instruments.

1FEB130783324A1A95242424D5C8A038.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design and construct simple weather instruments (e.g., wind vane, rain gauge, thermometer, barometer, and anemometer).

D6952E0CD00644B59A91C1DE0F618F68.description: Classify clouds as stratus, cumulus, cirrus, or “other”, compare results with others, and analyze why results may vary.

9B671E2C336C40C49F4701420764E69C.description: Compare strengths and limitations of methods and technologies used historically and currently by different people around the world to obtain information about the weather.

0777EDF7844D434EBA29257F5AA1EE3B.description: Pose questions about local weather conditions and methods of collecting weather data.

E62ACBDDA3A542B8BBE5A7CDFF1D10AD.description: Measure and represent local weather, including temperature, wind speed and direction, amount of sunlight, precipitation, relative humidity, and cloud cover

5E72FDA71FDE4E498817F36453E8C539.description: Imagine machines that could be developed to simplify tasks within their lives, including fanciful devices such as Rube Goldberg machines.

2972A4DD4B0543BC92337FDDD54F305B.description: Analyze the ways in which various combinations of simple machines can be combined to create complex machines.

6C2C153B8D494A0B9637D739B9349247.description: Analyze technologies that are based on principles of simple machines in sports and recreation (e.g., teeter-totter, water slide, gymnastics wedge, balance board, and roller coaster).

36F35B48E49E410683ACEEC0FAC3F10A.description: Examine the types of tasks in the community that have been and are being currently accomplished using wedges (e.g., shim, splitting maul, knife, axe, and chisel).

DEBA6E1753824DDBABDCA8231E33E024.description: Research the use of inclined planes and other simple machines used to construct structures such as pyramids, Stonehenge, Easter Island moai, tipis, inukshuks, and totem poles.

E217D944EB6D4F4FBD96797F9D2A5872.description: Examine how agricultural, industrial, automotive, marine, and household applications of pulleys (e.g., combine, swather, crane, fan belt, block and tackle, clothesline, and flagpole) have changed the lives of individuals and affected society and the environment.

754D0A62880840DCAF3F88C15B20AE2E.description: Assess the impacts of machines, such as carts, boats, airplanes, logging equipment, and tractors, on traditional lifestyles.

3708581AF9AA49AAB911811EA31E245D.description: Identify the benefits and disadvantages of practical examples of levers (e.g., pliers, teeter-totter, bottle opener, wheelbarrow, and fishing rod) on their lives and in their community.

F4DD2488129E48AFB840817527D2A122.description: Suggest how the function of common simple mechanisms, such as a crowbar, wheelbarrow, elbow joint, fork, rake, baseball bat, can opener, stapler, or scissors, might be different had they been based on a different class of lever.

5212043F832842E08F8CBF8C58A553A6.description: Assess, using student-identified criteria, the function and effectiveness of products designed to enhance or reduce friction (e.g., grease, oil, ski wax, skate blade, fishing lure, canoe paddle, Velcro, and winter tires) between two surfaces.

37A7256787054FBFA55C56C4FD7F0C16.description: Analyze the effects of forces from natural phenomena (e.g., earthquake, tornado, hurricane, and tsunami) on the natural and constructed environment.

12A25876E11C4654B7303D1EF9E69A7A.description: Compare technologies developed and/or used by various cultures, past and present, which represent applications of simple machines.

448E1E32D2C34D8CBF00F068529EB79C.description: Provide examples of simple and complex machines used at home, in school, and throughout their community.

F096B5CA1F854308B76D0DFE7E433B75.description: Assess how natural and man-made forces and simple machines affect individuals, society, and the environment.

EA4D8725D7224FB88BC1E4DC5D9D3B26.description: Pose new questions to investigate about the characteristics of simple machines.

74AEEBD3F017423E85925A56BBD4E6B2.description: Recognize that scientific processes and ideas help explain how and why simple machines operate.

3ADD909DEC88441C91248C7BB26B9ACA.description: Create a representation of the characteristics and operating principles of each type of simple machine.

902CF75745154279A415C61F7D050557.description: Evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of a prototype of a simple machine using student-identified criteria, and refine the prototype based on data.

90E610E04CAF42F9AF9FC712CBDB248C.description: Design and construct a prototype of a simple machine which is meant to accomplish a student-identified task.

989438B9A46D43D8AC4B68E62A7F5ECE.description: Explain the operating principles of an inclined plane, such as a ramp or ladder, with reference to the applied load and the distance that the load is moved.

908028E3118D483387EB5EA43AFCCFFF.description: Investigate the relationship between the amount of applied force and the distance that the load is moved in single and multiple pulley systems, including determining the mechanical advantage of the system.

232DD6080E21435CA6BDFDA02ABA7F8D.description: Determine the effectiveness of wheel and axle mechanisms (e.g., screwdrivers, wheels, doorknobs, and gear systems) of various diameters, rotational speeds, and rotational directions for accomplishing specific tasks.

33832BB6DEEF4C50857CA6503FEBB748.description: Compare the operation of wheel and axle mechanisms (e.g., Ferris wheel, bicycle wheel, rolling pin, in-line skate, windmill, and door knob) with the operation of levers.

C70567DE34474098B672EDB27E36F175.description: Determine the relationship between the applied force and the distance the load is moved for each class of lever

75AA764C8E454064A0F30F71E1E57E2A.description: Demonstrate how the position of the fulcrum, the load, and the applied force differs for each of the three classes of levers.

614B69B71823412EB9A27A947D1271EF.description: Design and carry out an experiment to compare the force needed to lift a load manually with that required to lift it using various simple machines.

BAC7924AA362463A809D8127AB0240C4.description: Select and safely use tools and materials in a manner that ensures personal safety and the safety of others when investigating the characteristics of simple machines.

2C8AAFD250E44A399154E0092F5FC926.description: Demonstrate how simple machines (e.g., hammer, screwdriver, pliers, bottle opener, ramp, splitting wedges, and scissors) act to reduce effort, increase the distance a load moves, and/or change the direction of an applied force.

F9D008548B3F43DFA77C2E4E4EAC91B1.description: Pose and refine testable questions about the operation of simple machines.

9635AE32DCC44A22A88DBEC5D915B238.description: Investigate characteristics of simple machines, including levers, wheels and axles, pulleys, inclined planes, screws, and wedges, for moving and lifting loads.

D384C1E2BC024CD09D67A51A29958C6B.description: Draw conclusions about the relationship between contact and non-contact forces on the movement of objects

5CBE9F7DC37C42188609D6D6292DF2F4.description: Evaluate methods used to investigate the effects of contact and non-contact forces on the movement of objects, including identifying and suggesting explanations for discrepancies in collected data.

881EAFF7A2134D16BA03F347CCBEC3A1.description: Collect and graph quantitative data to compare the mass and gravitational force acting on various objects.

242A4B72CBF84BCE9514A3C150CB2623.description: Measure forces in standard units (e.g., Newton) using a spring scale or a force sensor.

5BE1930C24894A609DA019F585F3C8BF.description: Collect and display quantitative data related to forces and motion using tables, charts, diagrams, and line graphs.

C1450506D3AB4F4E9914689F38B16AE5.description: Conduct a fair test to compare the effects of friction on the movement of objects over a variety of surfaces (e.g., wood, cloth, floor tile, carpet, tabletop, sidewalk, and grass).

3C7B9705FF214A839D14B2D92B0E8C6F.description: Pose questions to investigate the effects of friction on stationary and moving objects, and identify variables (e.g., surface material, texture, mass, angle of ramp, and orientation of object) that may be relevant to the investigation.

1D352D352EDA42A6832C2DE50DD51523.description: Differentiate between the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces (e.g., gravitational, magnetic, and mechanical) on the movement of objects.

DF6B6A00131B4011A3A40B7E7962AB2E.description: Record qualitative observations and quantitative measurements about the effects of non-contact (i.e., gravitational and magnetic) forces which act from a distance to cause objects to move, change direction, or stay in place.

F838DDE405FF4AE692C5C5FB5288BBF5.description: Measure, using non-standard units (e.g., number of elastic bands, and the length that an elastic band stretches), the force required to cause an object to move a specified distance, and estimate the force required to move a different object the same distance or the same object a different distance

2D5B1B8DD77F4049A910BC8680D238BB.description: Collaboratively design and carry out an experiment to determine the effects of changing the amount of force applied to an object on the movement of the object.

B577A83B83D645C8AE2CD6B6C625B8A3.description: Explain and diagram, using force arrows to represent the relative strength and direction of a force, how contact and non-contact forces affect the movement of objects.

B955942F871C4DB7852400AF6B76C38F.description: Describe how forces can act directly or from a distance to cause objects to start to move, speed up, slow down, change direction, or stop moving.

809071C71A564C3DAD61C31D150F60CD.description: Differentiate between examples of contact (e.g., wind, push, and pull) and non-contact (e.g., magnetic and gravitational) forces in their daily lives.

0C612CDA504C486994C7C03D99262E33.description: Analyze the effects of gravitational, magnetic, and mechanical forces, including friction, on the movement of objects.

0E8BBC7513E74CDF8F0A4446DD26591F.description: Physical Science: Forces and Simple Machines (FM)

86928E59D5C441E4807C3E78398C4E02.description: Recognize the need for developing a sense of responsibility towards other people, other living things, and the environment when choosing how to use and dispose of manufactured products

6B968D8BD42B4BB09AF74FABA23DD46E.description: Investigate how natural and manufactured products (e.g., tires, computers, trees, garbage, paper, scrap metal, house construction materials, food, clothing, oil, and automobiles) are disposed of personally, in their communities, and in Saskatchewan.

B2BD4FD6C2054058807FA3DAF8B41348.description: Research cultural values related to the consumption of products, such as using all parts of an animal.

64B42B21B8384490B38087976407A053.description: Identify potentially harmful products used at home, school, and in communities, including interpreting consumer chemical hazard symbols, and describe practices that individuals can follow to ensure personal and community safety.

DBED22E20F6145DABC6A4EF8C3FD402E.description: Assess the societal and environmental impacts of industrial and agricultural processes that change raw materials into manufactured products, taking into account different perspectives such as consumer, manufacturer, salesperson, and community leader

A6A7B03F47CC4F338C61707AA5711190.description: Identify locations in their communities and in Saskatchewan where agricultural and industrial manufacturing occurs, what products are created and tested, which raw materials are used, and how byproducts and waste are disposed.

E8457725AEE44A8383DD18FE5A127CF9.description: Develop and apply criteria (e.g., function, cost, reliability, and aesthetics) for evaluating the effectiveness of a consumer product.

4F80B05DAA284C2F91FA060772BD6E1B.description: Conduct a fair test to determine the effectiveness of different types or brands of a material (e.g., glue, coffee mug, paper towel, battery, bubble gum, paper, soap, and balloon).

1C428343C487440D9F7F9FC8B5F09611.description: Research a product to determine the raw materials from which it is made and the process required to turn the raw materials into a manufactured product.

7E48CA6B05F24D47A72B0E41030FA8BD.description: Assess the benefits and drawbacks of manufactured materials (e.g., plastic, steel, aluminium, glass, nylon, and other fabric) that have been developed to improve human living conditions.

5889B4BAB2F74B3499D7B1CA99D8984E.description: Differentiate between raw materials and manufactured products.

9231DAC4C15541778786FB48DF826238.description: Assess how the production, use, and disposal of raw materials and manufactured products affects self, society, and the environment.

18AC5C627AF940098162D8CE3F3683F0.description: Develop conclusions about the effects of reversible and nonreversible changes on the characteristics and physical properties of materials.

0A1D748C919841C68A9DA238558F2082.description: Investigate methods, such as firing clay and forming alloys (e.g., brass, bronze, white gold, and sterling silver) that artists use to change materials based on their understanding of the properties of materials.

03B36684809043D48F2F0C3F487E82C7.description: Discuss the characteristics of fair tests and why scientists value the importance of conducting fair tests for gaining knowledge about the physical properties of materials.

AE7850A6BA9940C78AE9926066F820F0.description: Follow established safety procedures for working with heating appliances and hot materials (e.g., switch hot plates off immediately after use, use tongs and insulated mitts for carrying hot materials and for tending a fire).

D485758C7CD9416599F721061B8037DE.description: Design and carry out a procedure to determine whether the mass of materials changes during reversible and non-reversible changes.

9123D180C89A44B5BF3CE74AED0AEEA8.description: Compare the characteristics and physical properties of a material in its solid and liquid states (e.g., compare the mass of ice cubes with the mass of liquid that results when they melt).

67CE5C0BD5FF431E9B30543FAD570764.description: Demonstrate that changes of state of matter are reversible when heat is applied or removed.

38D44E4A18CF4826A5C3F8FB7EAFED7D.description: Provide evidence of the six changes of state (i.e., evaporation, condensation, freezing, melting, sublimation, and deposition) of matter in the environment (e.g., water evaporating from wet clothes, steam condensing on the wall of a shower, lake freezing, butter melting, ice cube sublimating in the freezer, and frost forming on a car window).

F0EF7A184EC946598B05985C2DDA6F6D.description: Differentiate between changes to materials that occur rapidly (e.g., wood burning, explosives detonating, balloon popping, and glass breaking) and those that occur over extended periods (e.g., bicycle rusting, paint fading, and newspaper yellowing).

A18E54180AC648D5B9D8618AF81AF108.description: Observe and classify changes to materials as reversible (e.g., melting ice cube, dissolving salt in water, blowing up a balloon, and folding paper) and non-reversible (e.g., paper burning, egg cooking, bicycle rusting, balloon popping, and apple turning brown).

4A551065C7864A5D836636BB3DAE314E.description: Predict whether changes to a material will be reversible or nonreversible.

058B14C09D8B488CB29666080AE692CA.description: Explore how characteristics and physical properties of materials may change when they interact with one another.

4D83DFBD3F524901A4C975680934DA55.description: Demonstrate changes (e.g., cutting aluminium foil, forming clay, breaking wood, and crumpling paper) that can be made to an object without changing the properties of the material making up the object

8C31D76A83D64F97827509E89812A92A.description: Pose and refine questions for investigation related to changes in materials.

8EA02A5CFF394E46A2773C30D3B02A16.description: Investigate how reversible and non-reversible changes, including changes of state, alter materials

4172F21B8387475D9D38FD7958FDD30C.description: Critique personal and scientific classification systems of matter by identifying substances that are not easily classified as solids, liquids, or gases (e.g., butter, fat scraped off hides, fog, Jell-O, and wax).

873E9904992A41719254D558A586DB82.description: Explain how some characteristics and physical properties, such as melting point, boiling point, buoyancy, and solubility, help to distinguish materials from one another.

40C04A4119E14332816D7D8AA7F645EE.description: Measure the temperature, volume, and mass of materials using appropriate instruments (e.g., digital thermometer, ruler, tape measure, graduated cylinder, measuring cup, single-pan balance, and electronic scale) and standard units (e.g., 0C, cm3 , ml, and kg).

92A345290631453A896FFC176788C4A2.description: Determine the distinguishing characteristics which enable scientists to differentiate between solids, liquids, and gases.

F1A036F85E9C47A39212B8F73DB0779C.description: Observe and record characteristics and physical properties (e.g., colour, texture, mass, volume, hardness, flexibility, absorbency, strength, buoyancy, melting point, malleability, magnetism, and solubility) of different solids, liquids, and gases in their environment.

A23185745EC445CCA9F39CCEEDB3EDED.description: Pose questions related to the characteristics and physical properties of matter that are suitable for investigating using processes of science.

EBD4D3FA6F2649418D50F36CA3FE5675.description: Carry out a procedure to compare the mass of an object with the mass of its components.

C150BEDD717E46F8A3FC01326A78E84F.description: Discuss the importance of water, in all states of matter, as a sacred substance within First Nations and Métis cultures.

14E755AE3A534EE0AA0F0CEF4870989D.description: Classify materials in their environment as solids, liquids, or gases based on personal observation.

2C29670D70DE4DC5BA85745998266EC1.description: Recognize that matter is anything that has mass and takes up space.

AD4C4E02CA464E0CB12D9DD13E47C517.description: Investigate the characteristics and physical properties of materials in solid, liquid, and gaseous states of matter.

B4E96B5C4D6143DCB8178DF5A42272FA.description: Physical Science: Properties and Changes of Materials (MC)

8C1E5DCA0E2F40E2B778D894AF811EFB.description: Propose alterations to the human body that might enable humans to function more effectively to accomplish one or more typical daily tasks.

88774654D90C4EDEB99ED9E15D54BF03.description: Explain how the digestive and excretory systems work together to ensure that the body makes use of food that is eaten and disposes of waste.

BF79CC69A11D4E19960839DC8B08A897.description: Investigate the interdependence between the nervous system and other body systems for reacting to stimuli and controlling body functions

C5D8646BA5F44376B34A23272C2597DB.description: Research how the respiratory, digestive, and circulatory systems work together to move oxygen and nutrients throughout the human body.

956842AAEB6B45AA84765D8397EF9008.description: Represent, physically, dramatically, or visually, the interactions among the skeletal, muscular, and nervous systems that produce movement of the body or parts of the body

23B888C93F524D26A184A09117C4A6FF.description: Relate body changes, such as acne on the skin and growth of body hair, to human growth and development from birth to puberty.

AA1D1D5138064D4C9D5E4B130C0EA6E9.description: Pose questions to investigate or suggest practical problems to solve in relation to human body systems (e.g., How are the various systems connected to each other? Could one system live without the other systems? If not, why not? Why do we need to eat? Could we breathe without a diaphragm? Which organs work hard during exercise? Why do people sometimes become paralyzed due to an injury?).

737918F07E844ECE9AD465F85FF9976B.description: Assess how multiple human body systems function together to enable people to move, grow, and react to stimuli.

99468E7301AB4CED9FA07B430F7B39F0.description: Imagine how a human body might function or look if it did not have one or more of the major body systems.

85A28065637D41DD8BEAE2E6650440B4.description: Suggest explanations for patterns and discrepancies in data collected during investigations related to the structure and/or function of human body systems.

54A82EEFCE4C49979FB01CD3A5DBDFA3.description: Compile and display data from investigations related to the structure and/or function of human body systems using appropriate formats such as frequency tallies, tables, and bar graphs.

E314BABF1E314EA99E23C86A383F3C28.description: Design and carry out procedures, including identifying and controlling variables, to investigate the structure and/or function of one or more body systems (e.g., the influence of exercise on heart rate, the role of simulated saliva in starting the digestion process, and factors that influence a person’s response time).

A4D94D047AA84117A49FF409DC3CDFF7.description: Rephrase, into a testable form, questions about the structure and/ or function of one or more body systems.

22403EB13AF143289FD08055A2A61147.description: Suggest the processes that scientists might follow to investigate questions related to the structure and/or function of human body systems (e.g., Which factors affect breathing and heartbeat rate? How does the digestion process work? How much air do lungs hold? Why is blood red? Where does my food go?).

564487BA06FF413F909BD25968064AE8.description: Critique models in science, such as models of human organs, as representations of natural phenomena, objects, and/or physical processes.

E736134BDBFD444FA14761177080521F.description: Assess, in collaboration with other students, a model of an organ from a human body system to refine the model.

E1450293D9434B6099BDD43E658F6E77.description: Model the structure and/or function of one or more organs from the human digestive, excretory, respiratory, circulatory, nervous, muscular, or skeletal system.

7D55AA90594246EE9F1AE2F17EDAEAC0.description: Create a written and/or visual representation of the location of the major organs of at least two human body systems within the entire body.

DCE52F10DA514339A56AA7A57110A84D.description: Explain at least two functions of the human digestive, excretory, respiratory, circulatory, nervous, muscular, or skeletal systems.

08B157DE115A4FFDA7722C9F8C63A98E.description: Investigate the structure, function, and major organs of one or more human body systems such as the digestive, excretory, respiratory, circulatory, nervous, muscular, and skeletal systems.

D389C4860E15403BBCA5363AEBC94F67.description: Research the roles of different individuals and organizations within their communities that help support personal and community health.

A102DDDE5C304CAEB28565E6DC2608E3.description: Propose actions that individuals can take to minimize the harmful effects and maximize the beneficial effects of natural- and humancaused environmental factors (e.g., West Nile Virus, mosquitoes, pesticides, air quality, noise pollution, food safety, and water and wastewater treatment) on human health.

22386A9529A7497CB49C55206979F629.description: Assess the benefits of lifestyle choices (e.g., daily physical activity, proper nutrition, adequate sleep, appropriate hygiene practices, regular medical check-ups, and using safety equipment) that contribute to maintaining a healthy body.

3BE4D5B11B33471AAE65093BD15D1DF6.description: Compare personal diets and those of people who live in different communities and countries worldwide to Canada’s Food Guide and Canada’s Food Guide – First Nations, Métis, and Inuit.

C6E56017C47642FC8B04E501DE5030A2.description: Predict how the failure or removal of a specific organ in the human body system would affect an individual’s health.

AB954A30DB6F4060AE002D16F58BC16F.description: Relate the effects of common diseases to the organs or body systems they affect or are related to (e.g., heart attacks affect the circulatory system, epilepsy affects the nervous system, hepatitis affects the liver, gallstones affect the gall bladder, and asthma affects the respiratory system).

1D74D78472FF4ADF827EA6716796587D.description: Describe the function of technologies (e.g., defibrillator, soap, exercise equipment, and safety equipment) that have been developed to support personal health.

4AAA2210EB7646E6B1C7A7FF29D408AC.description: Research how the body’s defences, such as tears, saliva, skin, certain blood cells, and stomach secretions, work to fight against infections.

3C06888E00534F369007C55CA1BE503D.description: Analyze the role of the skin (e.g., protection, heat regulation, absorption, and evaporation) in maintaining a healthy body.

98E13042B9E84D5B9EFFE8F7EA2CF390.description: Identify local knowledge, including the effects of traditional lifestyles, that contributes to human understanding of maintaining a healthy body

9318E248C3574568A83A07DAA5E71667.description: Examine methods and perspectives of various cultures, including First Nations and Métis, which have contributed to knowledge about maintaining a healthy body (e.g., balance inherent in the Medicine Wheel).

454A703FEE484BDD9CEDAAA703D3103D.description: Analyze personal and societal requirements for, and the impact of, maintaining a healthy human body.
